div.head: Revisiting traditional isoglosses in the Maghreb: Methodology | Terminology | Classification; Algeria | Tunisia | Libya
Invitation to the Conference
div.p: In April 2019 we started our FWF-funded project titled Tunisia’s Linguistic terra incognita: An Investigation into the Arabic Varieties of Northwestern and Central Tunisia (TUNOCENT) in cooperation with the Austrian Academy of Sciences (ÖAW). In this project we want to provide up-to-date linguistic data for the hitherto almost unknown Arabic varieties spoken in the region approximating the seven Tunisian governorates of Jendouba, Beja, Kef, Siliana, Kasserine, Sidi Bouzid, and Gafsa. This region can be viewed as a unit because of its shared socio-linguistic (Bedouin-type dialects), socio-historical (semi-nomadism and sedentarization), socio-economic (weak economy, high unemployment, emigration), and topographical (mainly mountainous) character.

In 1950 the famous French dialectologist William Marçais affixed the term terra incognita - W. Marçais (1950:212) used the term 'ignota' instead (W. Marçais. 1950. “Les parlers arabes.” In: A. Basset (ed.) Initiation à la Tunisie. Paris, 195-219) - to Tunisian Bedouin-type dialects, differentiating them into what he called the H- (Hilāl) and S- (Sulaym) dialects. His judgement that further research into these almost completely unknown varieties is urgently needed still holds true now, almost 70 years later - G. Mion (2015: 270)writes of “En absence complète d’analyses sur la région intérieure du pays …” (G. Mion. 2015. “Réflexions sur la catégorie des «parlers villageois» en arabe tunisien.” Romano-Arabica XV, 269-277). Therefore, this project is the first attempt to linguistically illuminate a part of Tunisia which has long remained under-studied.

Now after almost three years of our project we want to look back to the first phases of our work that involved the recording and collecting of the linguistic data, as well as the transcription of certain questionnaires. Before starting the intensive task of describing, comparing and classifying these dialects, a discussion with experts on various fields of Maghrebi dialectology should enable a fruitful future work in this project.

This discussion should take place in the realm of an online-symposion organised by the Department of Near Eastern Studies of the University of Vienna in cooperation with the Austrian Centre for Digital Humanities and Cultural Heritage (ACDH-CH) of the Austrian Academy of Sciences. It will feature two (or probably three) days of presentations and discussions (2nd and 3rd of June 2022) and will take place online with the conference tool Zoom. Since you are one of the specialists in this particular field of Arabic dialectology we would like to invite you to participate in this conference.

For many regions of the Maghreb we still rely on classifications and categorizations that are almost hundred years old (e.g. those of William Marçais and Jean Cantineau). In the realm of our symposion we want to challenge the isoglosses that were mainly of phonological and morphological nature and investigate their significance in the modern linguistic landscape. As is well known, syntax has often been neglected in dialect studies and not been considered for isoglosses as it demands large corpora that are often not available to researchers. Our conference should stress the importance of (morpho-)syntactic phenomena for classifying dialects. To mention only a few, the role that agreement patterns, the use of the genitive marker and the dual, progressive markers, auxiliary verbs, subordinate clauses play in individual dialects and as possible isoglosses should be investigated.

The conference should improve our understanding of the complex relationship between the Tunisian dialects and those spoken in adjacent areas of Algeria and Libya. It should also provide new insights into the diachronic and synchronic linguistic situation in the central Maghreb.

Papers can touch on all fields of Arabic dialectology concerned with Tunisia, Algeria and Libya, and also relevant aspects dealing with digital approaches to Arabic dialectology:
- Questioning of traditional isoglosses, traditional terminology and traditional dialectal classifications
- Syntactic characteristics as isoglosses
- Phonological, morphological and syntactic aspects of Tunisian, Algerian and Libyan Arabic dialects
- Diachronic and synchronic aspects of various Tunisian, Algerian and Libyan dialects
- Descriptions of hitherto little or non-investigated Tunisian, Algerian and Libyan dialects
- Bedouin and sedentary dialects in comparison
- Youth language versus dialects of the older generations and other sociolinguistic aspects
- Dialect geography
- Methodological questions
- Development of koiné languages and prestige dialects
- Lexicon of Tunisian, Algerian and Libyan dialects
- Tunisian, Algerian, and Libyan dialects in their broader Maghrebinian context
- Digital humanities and Arabic dialects
